content: hello everyone why lock here welcome back thanks for joining me today I'm
going to build a knock tilith crown or attempt to mimic the model by Games
Workshop I found it to be a beautiful and intriguing model I like that it fits
in a sci-fi or fantasy setting and I could definitely see it being used not
just in my wargames but like in my Dungeons & Dragons sessions this thing
could even be like the focal point of a campaign so I can get a lot of mileage
out of it for the work that I put into it so I'm excited about that
anyways I'd like to show you how I built it
all right a few quick notes since I'm not big on preambles when I talk about
white PVA glue I like to use Elmer's any PVA glue will work hot glue I use my
trusty sure bonder I've used eight different types of glue guns over my
crafting career in the past six years this is by far the best one so sure
bonder when I refer to cardstock I use food box left over so that thickness of
material shiny on one side sort of rough on the other
and lastly chipboard this is stuff I use on the channel all the time it's the
stuff you find at the back of a legal pad but you can buy it in bulk so
there's links in the video description below to help you out with that
alright I think that covers the basics so let's get into the project and
remember that our sponsor is heroes hoard for you 3d printers out there
excellent selection including Altru tiles lines these are from a kids
ring-toss game I think my wife found them at Hobby Lobby they have some fine
ridges at the periphery should work great however they're
basically frisbee so there's this cavity underneath so I traced them onto some
chipboard cut out some rings and hot glued them in as spacers then I cut out
eight of these Diamond sort of shapes again from chipboard and hot glued them
in place equidistantly around the ring then it completed the sandwich with the
other ring
now this thin gap along the periphery needs to be covered up so I'll use some
cardstock strips for that and just hot glued them on same for the inside of the
Ring and then in between each spike is these rows of skulls so again I just got
strips of chipboard and hot glued those in place and made them wrap around the
outer edge to the other side then there's least like perpendicular bolt
housing things on each one of those so I went to my beads bin and found these
sort of elongated beads with glyphs on them and I just super glued those in
place a gel control superglue on one surface and some superglue accelerant on
the other creates an instant bond and I like to be kind of generous with this I
mean I put a good dab there so I get a lot of surface area for the cured glue
found this package of craft jewels at the dollar store for a buck the small
ones are perfect for rivets so with tweezers and white PVA glue like Elmer's
I put two in between each rim feature for the base of this thing I started
with a rectangle of cardstock that fits between three spikes and cut out a hole
in the middle for the middle one then just hot glued that on with that done I
trace this curve on to some foam board and then we just sort of studied the
model and tried to mimic the shape of the pedestal legs with that as a master
I traced and made four copies and then on cardstock I traced it again
but I also cut away some sections from the middle again to sort of mimic the
original model I used my new exacto knife for this and I cannot believe it
took me six years to try one out this thing is life-changing anyway then I
white glued those to each foot then I cut some toothpick tips and hot glued
those on to that lower rim and sandwiched them with another strip of
cardstock Spike's gotta have spikes a pre-drilled holes with a toothpick
filled them with white glue and then
inserted toothpick tips next up I chopped 3 squares doesn't really matter
what size or shape these are just a spacer I stacked three of them together
and attached a leg to each side and now the moment of truth hot gluing one leg
at a time to that bottom curve have a few seconds of working time to shift it
around and make sure that it's straight and parallel and it went okay then it
was time for more riveting decorating up that pedestal filigree again white glue
and it helped to use a toothpick to apply the glue don't need much also
notice wherever possible I had the shiny product side of the
cardstock always facing in because that brown paper side takes glue and paint
much better here's a chain I got from the necklace making aisle at the craft
store when attached both ends with portions of paper clip
and so again super glue and accelerant trick again you can see a kind of
healthy blobs of hot glue there I want the ends of the paperclip really
be submerged and have meaningful surface area watch this it's so cool it turns to
cement right in front of your eyes and look at this it's already load-bearing
the other end I attach to the feet again two pre-drilled holes but using hot glue
this time I wanted speed but super glue will melt the foam and white glue takes
too long looking at my leftover chaos bits here's some chains and skulls from
a chaos rhino hot glued one on each side then I whipped up these skull plaques in
3ds Max and 3d printed them and white glued them onto those ribs on the ring
lastly I measured out a card stock ring
to fit over the green part but chopped away those rib portions and cut each
panel into it's easier to just show this than to describe their see two panels
between each rib just hot glued on an outside for primer lately I prefer gray
primers no matter what I'm doing they just seem to be the most durable and
give the fullest coverage and the fastest dry time one thing I forgot to
mention and forgot to film anywhere you see white foam board I painted over with
a healthy coat of white PVA glue and let it dry this was to protect it from the
accelerant in the spray paint looking good all primed up and now painting I
want to start with this pavement color it's a really dark grey and I wanted to
tint it slightly and I mean very slightly blue so I added a dash of navy
blue mixed it up perfect solid base coat on the body of the ring
followed by a black wash just a very very diluted black acrylic paint with
that dry I mixed in a small dash of light gray to that base color and used
it to edge highlight all those panels and to dry brush all the spikes the
fibrous texture of that chipboard really does all the work for you it's great
with a rich metallic gold color i base coated those skull things and with a
metallic gunmetal the entire base and the perimeter strips basically anywhere
that there's rivets or chains all of that done I washed the gunmetal with
black this time I actually used army painter dark tone a proper shade instead
of paint it just gives a little better result and on the gold bits
I used army painter soft tone just a light brown wash and slathered it on
there highlighting I dry brushed metallic silver over all the gun metal
parts and a very light polished gold over the skulls
then I got out this vieo environmental effect paint for doing rust I used this
to great success a few videos ago when we did the scratch built promethium
pipes so I dabbed around each rivet and added some random splotches and streaks
plus hit the chains and spikes and that perimeter strip as well and now for the
runes I simply took a metallic bronze and free-handed these I looked at the
reference art and just duplicated all those glyphs easy enough for the red
glow on the perimeter I'm gonna base with a dark red and then
make those pulsing bright spots with an orange II sort of red so it's true the
airbrush I go and first the base coat by the way this is an eye wada HPC s
outstanding airbrush able to draw a very fine bead like this and then just spritz
down those three glowing spots in each segment just like the reference picture
first we'll take a look at it up close and then I'll show it to you on the
table in context now it's kind of laughing about this with my wife because
this model costs anywhere between forty and fifty dollars but to craft it you
only need to spend ninety if I had to guess if I were sourcing all this
material from scratch it would be something more than fifty dollars but I
happen to have it all on hand because I'm a crafter and I've made tons of
other terrain so I got lots of leftover supplies to pick from by and large I am
really happy with how this came out I think it captures the original models
spirit pretty well and it actually I mean up close you can see a lot of the
sins but from three feet away it actually looks pretty darn good in
person so here we go I've set up a little scene with some custodians
attacking some Black Legion Owen this big old terrain piece that it's sitting
on with the skull and everything I'm building that in the next
it's either the next episode of the one after so feel free to subscribe so you
get the reminder when that comes out I didn't plan this but I guess it makes
sense that my Black Legion ended up matching this thing pretty well color
wise it fits right in I'll just read to you here directly from
the Games Workshop website says knock tilith crowns are
edifis is raised up by the chaos space marines to weaken the very foundations
of reality crafted from the mysterious material known as black stone these vast
psychic resonators in the veil to deadly effect so just for those of you totally
unfamiliar with like Warhammer 40k or wargaming the presence of this model and
its proximity to other models on the table affects them somehow in this case
it's a boon to chaos Space Marines and a malice to everyone else I also want to
relay a tip I coincidentally heard recently on the YouTube channel miscast
the more detail you put into a build the more you can get away with a simple or
sloppy paint job I think for this project that rings absolutely true if
you're new to the idea of crafting for your tabletop gaming be sure and find us
on the tabletop crafters guild on Facebook also lots of the links in the
description below resources for you to check out and here's two other projects
that based on today's project I think you'll like till I see you nextime why
lock make things and play games
